Description: Mould-cast glass plaque of female figure, possibly Astarte, pierced for suspension as a pendant; naked; standing on a square plinth; holding breasts; rather pronounced belly; large navel, probably accidentally formed by the bursting of a bubble during or after casting; wearing a broad necklace indicated by short vertical lines, and possible fillet around the forehead; shoulder-length hair curled at the ends is indicated by parallel vertical lines; rod-formed horizontal perforation at chest level; originally probably translucent dark blue, faded to opaque light bluish-grey.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Tell Atchana, AT/39/106 Level V
Curator's comments: Originally mis-identified as frit and popularly albeit uncertainly identified as Astarte. Numerous examples of this type have been found in Late Bronze Age contexts dating from the late 16th-13th centuries BC, with a distribution ranging from Mesopotamia (Nuzi, Tell al-Rimah) and Anatolia (Hattusha) to Syro-Palestine (Alalakh, Beth Shan, Ebla, Hama, Lachish, Megiddo), Cyprus (Kouklia, Milia), Greece (Kakovatos, Mycenae, Tholos A) and Egypt (Asyut).
Bibliographic references: Barag 1985a / Catalogue of Western Asiatic glass in the British Museum, Volume I (15; p. 45, pl. 2)
Tait 1991 / Five Thousand Years of Glass (fig. 18, p.24)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2014 - 2015 27 Nov - 10 May, Leiden, Rijksmuseum van Oudheden, 'Carthage' Room 57: Ancient Syria [Syrian Room], case 6, Easter 1982-.
Condition: The original colour has faded but still retains a light bluish tinge; iridescent; many cracks; repaired.
